user_prompt: From 'If the essay is well-written, then the student will get an A', can we infer 'If the essay is well-written and turned in late, then the student will get an A'?
system_prompt:
When evaluating conditional statements, remember that real-world conditionals often have implicit background assumptions and normal conditions built in. Don't apply formal logical rules mechanically without considering whether additional conditions in the antecedent might contradict these implicit assumptions.

After considering these factors, write 'Answer: ' followed by only 'yes' or 'no' and nothing else.

responses.content:
Let me work through this carefully.

The original statement is: "If well-written, then A"
The proposed inference is: "If well-written AND turned in late, then A"

From a formal logic perspective, this inference is **invalid**. Here's why:

In formal logic, if we have P → Q, we cannot validly infer (P ∧ R) → Q. Adding an additional condition to the antecedent doesn't preserve the truth of the consequent.

More importantly, in the real-world context of grading:
- The original statement likely operates under the implicit assumption of normal conditions (e.g., the essay is submitted on time, follows requirements, etc.)
- "Turned in late" contradicts this normal background assumption
- Late submission typically triggers penalties that override other positive factors
- So adding "turned in late" to the antecedent actually undermines the original conditional's applicability

The original conditional's guarantee of an A depends on meeting standard expectations. Late submission violates those expectations, so we cannot infer that the consequent (getting an A) still holds.

Answer: no
